title: Colorectal Cancer Rates in Younger People

content: The news from my gastroenterologist hit me like a ton of bricks.

After my first colonoscopy at age 51, he called to say he’d removed three precancerous growths during the procedure. Why was I so surprised? I have no family history of cancer, I don’t smoke, my alcohol intake was low, my weight was within a normal range, I exercised regularly, and I ate the suggested amount of fiber every day as part of a balanced diet.

Colorectal cancer (CRC) almost always begins with precancerous polyps, or growths, in the colon or rectum. Being over 50 is a known risk factor for these abnormal polyps, so I really shouldn’t have been so put out about my test results.
Here’s what’s really puzzling, though: CRC in adults under age 50 is increasing at an alarming rate.

Colorectal cancer is now the number one cause of cancer-related deaths in men 20 to 49 years old in the U.S. and the second leading cause of death in women of the same age. Though screening for cancer has improved, experts say the increase in cancer cases cannot be entirely explained by better detection.

sections.heading: Why Are Younger People Getting CRC?
content: Cancer is complicated, and the rise in CRC in people under 50 is likely due to more than one factor. While genetics plays a role in a small portion of cases in the under-50 crowd, experts think that most CRC in this age group is probably linked to the environment and lifestyle.

Having obesity can cause abnormal insulin metabolism throughout the body, including in the gut, where it helps support gut tissue and prevents gut dysbiosis. Gut dysbiosis refers to reduced variety, or diversity, within the gut microbiome, an enormous community of mostly beneficial bacteria that help regulate digestion and overall health. Gut dysbiosis contributes to inflammation, which increases CRC risk. Younger people with CRC tend to have a less diverse gut microbiome than older people with CRC.
Drinking alcohol raises the risk of CRC and six other types of cancer. Alcohol damages cells, encourages inflammation, and increases the body’s uptake of cancer-causing substances.

content: Frequent consumption of processed meats such as deli meat, bacon, jerky, and hot dogs, as well as fresh red meats including beef, pork, and lamb, may increase CRC risk. Nitrates and nitrites, added to processed meat for freshness, can damage cells in the colon and rectum. Grilling and frying processed and fresh red meat produces substances that can also harm cells.

Research has found adequate calcium intakes are linked to less colon cancer, but most adults don’t get enough calcium. Dairy products are the most concentrated source of natural calcium. Kefir and yogurt with added cultures contribute beneficial bacteria to the colon, which may help fight off damage to colon cells.
How to Reduce Your Risk of Colorectal Cancer

A healthy lifestyle helps to offset the chances of developing CRC at any age. Though the body has tools to repair cell damage that can lead to cancer, it pays to do everything you can to protect cells, especially if you’re under 50.
bullets: Achieve and maintain a healthy weight with a balanced eating plan and regular physical exercise.
Enjoy two to three servings of dairy foods daily to get the calcium you need.
Limit processed and red meats and substitute more chicken, fish, beans, lentils, and soy foods, such as tofu, edamame, and tempeh.

Include at least 30 grams of fiber daily. Dietary fiber, found only in plant foods, feeds the beneficial gut bacteria that play a role in warding off cell damage. Plant foods contain compounds called polyphenols that also nourish gut bacteria. Eat a wide array of plant foods to help support gut diversity.
Don’t smoke. Smoking raises the risk of CRC and several other kinds of cancer.

Limit or avoid alcohol. Men should have no more than two standard drinks daily, while women should have no more than one, if that. A standard drink is 12 ounces of regular beer, 5 ounces of wine, or 1.5 ounces of 80-proof alcohol.

sections.heading: Don’t Ignore the Signs of Colorectal Cancer
content: Removing precancerous polyps prevents them from turning into cancer, but you can’t find them without screening, including colonoscopy or home testing. The earlier the detection, the better, because that’s when treatment is most effective.

content_blocks.text: Removing precancerous polyps prevents them from turning into cancer, but you can’t find them without screening, including colonoscopy or home testing. The earlier the detection, the better, because that’s when treatment is most effective.

content: The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force recommends testing for colorectal cancer starting at age 45, down from age 50. You may need to start testing earlier or more often if you have a personal or family history of colorectal cancer, colorectal polyps, Crohn’s disease, or ulcerative colitis.

If you notice anything different or alarming at any age, talk to your doctor right away. Research that pooled the results of 81 studies found that nearly half of the people with early-onset CRC had symptoms such as bright red blood in the stool or on toilet paper after a bowel movement and abdominal pain, while 25% of people had altered bowel habits, such as diarrhea. The results also showed it was four to six months and often longer between the first symptoms appearing and getting a diagnosis of CRC.
